Package infodynamics.measures.continuous.gaussian

Class TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo
      • infodynamics.measures.continuous.TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateViaCondMutualInfo
        • infodynamics.measures.continuous.gaussian.TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorCommon, ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous, TransferEntropyCalculator, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariate, AnalyticNullDistributionComputer, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
    public class TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian
extends TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateViaCondMutualInfo
implements AnalyticNullDistributionComputer

    Computes the differential transfer entropy (TE) between two multivariate double[][] time-series of observations (implementing TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariate), assuming that the probability distribution function for these observations is a multivariate Gaussian distribution. TE was defined by Schreiber, extended to multivariate source and destination by Lizier et al. (2011), and Kaiser and Schreiber showed how to compute TE via Gaussian assumption. This estimator is realised here by plugging in ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian as the calculator into the parent class TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateViaCondMutualInfo.

    That is, this class implements a multivariate TE calculator using model of Gaussian variables with linear interactions, making it equivalent (up to a multiplicative constant) to the multivariate Granger causality (see Barnett et al below).

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariate, with:

    • The constructor step being a simple call to TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian().
    • setProperty(String, String) allowing properties defined for both TransferEntropyCalculator.setProperty(String, String) and ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian.setProperty(String, String) as outlined in TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.setProperty(String, String)).
    • The user can call setCovariance(double[][], int) instead of supplying observations via TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateViaCondMutualInfo.setObservations(double[][], double[][]) or TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateViaCondMutualInfo.addObservations(double[][], double[][]) etc.
    • Computed values are in nats, not bits!
    • Additional method computeSignificance() to compute null distribution analytically.

    References:

    • T. Schreiber, "Measuring information transfer", Physical Review Letters 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000.
    • J.T. Lizier, J. Heinzle, A. Horstmann, J.-D. Haynes, M. Prokopenko, "Multivariate information-theoretic measures reveal directed information structure and task relevant changes in fMRI connectivity", Journal of Computational Neuroscience, vol. 30, pp. 85-107, 2011.
    • L. Barnett, A. B. Barrett, A. K. Seth, "Granger Causality and Transfer Entropy Are Equivalent for Gaussian Variables", Physical Review Letters 103 (23) 238701, 2009;
    • A. Kaiser, T. Schreiber, "Information transfer in continuous processes", Physica D, Vol. 166, No. 1-2., pp. 43-62 (2002).
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier, email, www
    See Also:

      • COND_MI_CALCULATOR_GAUSSIAN

        public static final java.lang.String COND_MI_CALCULATOR_GAUSSIAN
        Name of the Gaussian conditional MI calculator we will use

      • PROP_MAX_CORR_NUM_SURROGATES

        public static final java.lang.String PROP_MAX_CORR_NUM_SURROGATES
        Property name for the number of surrogates to use in computing the bias correction if required for the auto embedding method in TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo. Defaults to 0 meaning that we use analytic bias correction rather than empirical surrogates. Note: This is not used for bias correction of the raw values, only for auto-embedding
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • auto_embed_num_surrogates

        protected int auto_embed_num_surrogates
        Internal variable for storing the number of surrogates to use for the auto-embedding in TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo. 0 mean we use analytic approaches rather than surrogates.

    • Method Detail

      • setCovariance

        public void setCovariance​(double[][] covariance,
                          int numObservations)
                   throws java.lang.Exception

        Set the joint covariance of the distribution for which we will compute the transfer entropy.

        Note that without setting any observations, you cannot later call TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.computeLocalOfPreviousObservations(), and without providing the means of the variables, you cannot later call TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateViaCondMutualInfo.computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][], double[][]).

        Parameters:
        covariance - joint covariance matrix of the multivariate source, dest, dest history variables, considered together.
        numObservations - the number of observations that the covariance was determined from. This is used for later significance calculations
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for covariance matrix not matching the expected dimensions, being non-square, asymmetric or non-positive definite

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty​(java.lang.String propertyName,
                        java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets properties for the TE Gaussian MultiVariate calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • PROP_MAX_CORR_NUM_SURROGATES -- number of surrogates to use to compute the bias correction in the auto-embedding if the property TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD has been set to one of the bias-corrected maximisation methods. Defaults to 0 meaning that we use analytic bias correction. Note: this is not used for other bias-correction, only inside auto-embedding
        • Any properties accepted by {@link super#setProperty(String, String)}
        • Or properties accepted by the underlying MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian.setProperty(String, String) implementation.
        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface TransferEntropyCalculator
        Overrides:
        setProperty in class TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if there is a problem with the supplied value).

      • computeSignificance

        public ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance()
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate an analytic distribution of what the TE would look like, under a null hypothesis that our variables had no relation (in the context of the conditional value). This is performed without bootstrapping (which is done in #computeSignificance(int, int) and #computeSignificance(int, int[][])). The method is implemented using the corresponding method of the underlying ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below, and the other papers referenced in AnalyticNullDistributionComputer.computeSignificance() (in particular Geweke), for a description of how this is done for TE and conditional MI. Basically, the null distribution is a chi-square distribution.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface AnalyticNullDistributionComputer
        Returns:
        ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution object which describes the proportion of TE scores from the null distribution which have higher or equal conditional MIs to our actual value.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."
